The taco stand in the atrium of the new College of Business building carried two items, fish tacos and chicken tacos. The fish tacos sell for \$15 and are made out of \$5 of ingredients and the chicken tacos sell for \$10 and are made out of \$4 of ingredients. Some days the taco stand owner has only chicken at his disposal, so he makes nothing but chicken tacos, and some days the opposite is true and he makes only fish tacos. Any fish or chicken tacos that do not sell at the end of the day can be sold for \$1 each as bait. On days when both proteins are available, the taco stand manager prefers to make a few of each kind. All tacos are made in his home kitchen and then transported to campus. Due to time constraints and the capacity of his pickup truck bed, he is limited to beginning each day with only 3000 tacos. Faced with a 3000 taco capacity constraint, what is the optimal number of chicken tacos to prepare?

\[ C + F = 3000 \]

- The profit from selling one chicken taco is \( \$10 - \$4 = \$6 \).

- The profit from selling any unsold tacos for \( \$1 \) each is \( \$1 \) per taco.

\[ \text{Expected Profit} = 6C + 10F + 1 \times (3000 - C - F) \]

\[ \text{Expected Profit} = 6C + 10F \]

Substituting \( F = 3000 - C \) into the profit equation, we get:

\[ \text{Expected Profit} = 6C + 10(3000 - C) = 6C + 30000 - 10C = 30000 - 4C \]

To maximize the profit, we need to minimize \( 4C \). This means we should maximize \( C \) while ensuring that the demand for chicken tacos does not exceed 2500. Therefore, the optimal number of chicken tacos to prepare is 2500, which also means the number of fish tacos prepared is:

\[ F = 3000 - C = 3000 - 2500 = 500 \]

Thus, the optimal number of chicken tacos to prepare is \(\boxed{2500}\).
